channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Freudian scripts and sensory slips: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02084-3

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Freudian scripts and sensory slips: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Digging deep for India’s water solution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02087-0

Vishwanath Srikantaiah works to restore India’s historic wells to provide better protection for water resources.
item.dc:title: Digging deep for India’s water solution
item.dc:creator: Alexia Austin

item.title: Does Ozempic boost fertility? What the science says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02045-w

Blockbuster weight-loss drugs have been linked to unexplained pregnancies. Research shows it is plausible, but more data is needed.
item.dc:title: Does Ozempic boost fertility? What the science says
item.dc:creator: Gillian Dohrn

item.title: How the grid came to shape the US landscape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02083-4

Science and reason underpinned early surveys, but sociopolitical ideals left their mark on the nation too, a historical account concludes.
item.dc:title: How the grid came to shape the US landscape
item.dc:creator: K. John Holmes

item.title: How the Lindau conference helps early-career researchers tap into a global network of Nobel laureates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02086-1

Past attendees of the Lindau meeting advise on how to make the most of the event and reap lasting career rewards.
item.dc:title: How the Lindau conference helps early-career researchers tap into a global network of Nobel laureates
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Publisher Correction: Fabrication of red-emitting perovskite LEDs by stabilizing their octahedral structure

item.title: Families given cash with no strings spend more money on kids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02097-y

Monthly cash transfers reduce risk of poverty — and higher amounts do not lead to higher spending on tobacco or alcohol.
item.dc:title: Families given cash with no strings spend more money on kids

item.title: Galapagos battles goats and tourists in 1974
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02088-z

Imports threaten the natural environment of Darwin’s favourite islands, and a reader ponders the longevity of carps, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Galapagos battles goats and tourists in 1974

item.title: How researchers navigate a PhD later in life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02109-x

Personal circumstances and commitments often add to the pressures faced by older graduate students. Nature sought advice from some who have risen to the challenge.
item.dc:title: How researchers navigate a PhD later in life
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Landau

item.title: First ever rocks from the Moon’s far side have landed on Earth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02101-5

Scientists are eager to work on Chang’e-6 rock samples, which touched down in the Chinese autonomous region Inner Mongolia today.
item.dc:title: First ever rocks from the Moon’s far side have landed on Earth
item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.title: You’re not imagining it: extreme wildfires are now more common
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02071-8

For the first time, data show that cataclysmic infernos are increasing in frequency and intensity globally.
item.dc:title: You’re not imagining it: extreme wildfires are now more common
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Autoimmune antibodies tied to lower malaria risk in kids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02018-z

Findings support one idea about why self-directed immune responses are more common in some populations.
item.dc:title: Autoimmune antibodies tied to lower malaria risk in kids

item.title: Gigantic oddball aurora seen from Earth for the first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02072-7

A camera captured the vast, diffuse glow produced after the solar wind dropped to a whisper.
item.dc:title: Gigantic oddball aurora seen from Earth for the first time
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: ‘Fantastic’ particle could be most energetic neutrino ever detected
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02074-5

The ultra-high-energy neutrino was spotted by deep-sea detectors and could point to a massive cosmic event.
item.dc:title: ‘Fantastic’ particle could be most energetic neutrino ever detected
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: The last few miles: how to prepare for the late-career stage in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02093-2

It can be daunting to see the final chapter of your career approaching. Planning ahead can help.
item.dc:title: The last few miles: how to prepare for the late-career stage in science
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Open-washing’ plagues big AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02103-3

Open-source artificial intelligence is nowhere near as open as its name would suggest, low-frequency vibrations arouse genital nerve cells in mice and why we must put people at the heart of schizophrenia research.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Open-washing’ plagues big AI
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Gut microbiome discovery provides roadmap for life-saving cancer therapies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02070-9

The balance between bacterial communities in the gut affects the likelihood of a positive response to drugs called checkpoint inhibitors.
item.dc:title: Gut microbiome discovery provides roadmap for life-saving cancer therapies
item.dc:creator: Giorgia Guglielmi

item.title: Author Correction: Extensive halogen-mediated ozone destruction over the tropical Atlantic Ocean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07649-w

Author Correction: Extensive halogen-mediated ozone destruction over the tropical Atlantic Ocean
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Extensive halogen-mediated ozone destruction over the tropical Atlantic Ocean

item.title: How huge black holes sprouted just after the Big Bang
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01703-3

Hubble observations of faint galaxies suggest that such objects could have been the seeds of very early supermassive black holes.
item.dc:title: How huge black holes sprouted just after the Big Bang

item.title: What’s the state of hiring researchers in science? Share your insights with Nature
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02062-9

Our first global survey of research group leaders and other hiring managers seeks to capture recruitment highs and lows in the current climate.
item.dc:title: What’s the state of hiring researchers in science? Share your insights with Nature
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: A mighty river’s radical shift changed the face of ancient Egypt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02014-3

Samples taken near a capital of the pharaohs reveal an overhaul of the Nile 4,000 years ago.
item.dc:title: A mighty river’s radical shift changed the face of ancient Egypt

item.title: ‘Smart’ fabric protects against heat of city streets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02019-y

Textile keeps its cool even when surrounded by urban surfaces that absorb and release heat.
item.dc:title: ‘Smart’ fabric protects against heat of city streets

item.title: Language is primarily a tool for communication rather than thought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07522-w

Evidence from neuroscience and related fields suggests that language and thought processes operate in distinct networks in the human brain and that language is optimized for communication and not for complex thought.
item.dc:title: Language is primarily a tool for communication rather than thought
item.dc:creator: Evelina Fedorenko
Steven T. Piantadosi
Edward A. F. Gibson

item.title: An alternative broad-specificity pathway for glycan breakdown in bacteria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07574-y

A screen of a human gut microbiome metagenomic library reveals a cluster of enzymes with an unconventional mechanism and an extremely broad substrate scope.
item.dc:title: An alternative broad-specificity pathway for glycan breakdown in bacteria
item.dc:creator: Seyed Amirhossein Nasseri
Aleksander C. Lazarski
Imke L. Lemmer

Stephen G. Withers

item.title: Detecting hallucinations in large language models using semantic entropy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07421-0

Hallucinations (confabulations) in large language model systems can be tackled by measuring uncertainty about the meanings of generated responses rather than the text itself to improve question-answering accuracy.
item.dc:title: Detecting hallucinations in large language models using semantic entropy
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Farquhar
Jannik Kossen
Lorenz Kuhn
Yarin Gal

item.title: Control of proton transport and hydrogenation in double-gated graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07435-8

Independent control of the electric field and charge-carrier density in double-gated graphene allows the decoupling of proton transport and lattice hydrogenation, enabling both accelerated proton transport and proton-based logic operations.
item.dc:title: Control of proton transport and hydrogenation in double-gated graphene
item.dc:creator: J. Tong

item.title: Room-temperature spin injection across a chiral perovskite/III–V interface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07560-4

By using a chiral halide perovskite material, spin injection at room temperature into a conventional III–V semiconductor multiple quantum well light-emitting diode is demonstrated, resulting in a semiconductor platform that can also control spin.
item.dc:title: Room-temperature spin injection across a chiral perovskite/III–V interface

item.title: Large-scale neurophysiology and single-cell profiling in human neuroscience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07405-0

This Perspective considers the implications of advances in human physiology, single-cell and spatial transcriptomics and long-term culture of resected human brain tissue for the study of network-level activity in human neuroscience.
item.dc:title: Large-scale neurophysiology and single-cell profiling in human neuroscience
item.dc:creator: Anthony T. Lee
Edward F. Chang
Mercedes F. Paredes
Tomasz J. Nowakowski

item.title: Tunable superconductivity in electron- and hole-doped Bernal bilayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07584-w

Tunable superconductivity and a series of flavour-symmetry-breaking phases are observed in electron- and hole-doped Bernal bilayer graphene.
item.dc:title: Tunable superconductivity in electron- and hole-doped Bernal bilayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Chushan Li

item.title: Multiscale topology classifies cells in subcellular spatial transcriptomics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07563-1

A method for topological automatic cell type classification across subcellular resolution spatial transcriptomic platforms is proposed, resolving cell type information and locating sparsely dispersed cells in human kidney and mouse kidney and brain.
item.dc:title: Multiscale topology classifies cells in subcellular spatial transcriptomics
item.dc:creator: Katherine Benjamin

item.title: Amazon forest biogeography predicts resilience and vulnerability to drought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07568-w

Drought response is structured by water-table depth in higher-fertility Southern Amazonia, whereas lower-fertility Northern Amazonia supports more-drought-resilient forests independent of water-table depth.
item.dc:title: Amazon forest biogeography predicts resilience and vulnerability to drought
item.dc:creator: Shuli Chen

item.title: Single-cell and spatial atlases of spinal cord injury in the Tabulae Paralytica
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07504-y

The Tabulae Paralytica, a compilation of four molecular atlases of spinal cord injury, provides a window into the pathobiology of spinal cord injury, establishing a framework for integrating multimodal, genome-scale measurements in four dimensions to study biology and medicine.
item.dc:title: Single-cell and spatial atlases of spinal cord injury in the Tabulae Paralytica
item.dc:creator: Michael A. Skinnider

item.title: Krause corpuscles are genital vibrotactile sensors for sexual behaviours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07528-4

Krause corpuscles of the clitoris and penis are highly sensitive mechanical vibration detectors that mediate sexually dimorphic mating behaviours in mice.
item.dc:title: Krause corpuscles are genital vibrotactile sensors for sexual behaviours
item.dc:creator: Lijun Qi
Michael Iskols

item.title: Human SARS-CoV-2 challenge uncovers local and systemic response dynamics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07575-x

A human SARS-CoV-2 challenge study in individuals without previous exposure to the virus or vaccines provides detailed profiles of local and systemic epithelial and immune cell response dynamics over time and infection status.
item.dc:title: Human SARS-CoV-2 challenge uncovers local and systemic response dynamics
item.dc:creator: Rik G. H. Lindeboom

item.title: Atomic dynamics of electrified solid–liquid interfaces in liquid-cell TEM
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07479-w

The development of advanced polymer electrochemical liquid cells for transmission electron microscopy allows direct monitoring of the atomic dynamics of electrified solid–liquid interfaces during copper-catalysed CO2 electroreduction reactions.
item.dc:title: Atomic dynamics of electrified solid–liquid interfaces in liquid-cell TEM
item.dc:creator: Qiubo Zhang

item.title: Computational design of soluble and functional membrane protein analogues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07601-y

A deep learning approach enables accurate computational design of soluble and functional analogues of membrane proteins, expanding the soluble protein fold space and facilitating new approaches to drug screening and design.
item.dc:title: Computational design of soluble and functional membrane protein analogues

item.title: A molecular and cellular perspective on human brain evolution and tempo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07521-x

This Perspective views brain development in terms of developmental tempo along the human lineage and reviews the contributions of recent technical advances to our understanding of neurodevelopment.
item.dc:title: A molecular and cellular perspective on human brain evolution and tempo
item.dc:creator: Feline W. Lindhout
Fenna M. Krienen
Katherine S. Pollard
Madeline A. Lancaster

item.title: The mechanism for directional hearing in fish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07507-9

A study demonstrates that the fish Danionella cerebrum is able to discriminate the direction of sound by comparing the relative phase of pressure and particle motion.
item.dc:title: The mechanism for directional hearing in fish
item.dc:creator: Johannes Veith
Thomas Chaigne
Ana Svanidze
Lena Elisa Dressler
Maximilian Hoffmann
Ben Gerhardt
Benjamin Judkewitz

item.title: Glassy gels toughened by solvent
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07564-0

Solvating polar polymers with ionic liquids at appropriate concentrations can produce a unique class of materials called glassy gels with desirable properties of both glasses and gels.
item.dc:title: Glassy gels toughened by solvent
item.dc:creator: Meixiang Wang
Xun Xiao

item.title: Direct radical functionalization of native sugars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07548-0

A radical-based method for functionalizing native sugars shows a way to remove typical protecting-group manipulations.
item.dc:title: Direct radical functionalization of native sugars

item.title: dsRNA formation leads to preferential nuclear export and gene expression
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07576-w

Antisense RNAs boost gene expression by accelerating the export of mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm through the Dbp2-mediated formation of double-stranded RNAs, which might explain the prevalence of antisense RNAs.
item.dc:title: dsRNA formation leads to preferential nuclear export and gene expression
item.dc:creator: Ivo Coban
Jan-Philipp Lamping
Anna Greta Hirsch
Sarah Wasilewski
Orr Shomroni
Oliver Giesbrecht
Gabriela Salinas
Heike Krebber

item.title: Dynamic stereomutation of vinylcyclopropanes with metalloradicals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07555-1

A Ni(I) metalloradical catalyst enables reversible cis/trans-isomerization of vinylcyclopropanes under chiral inversion.
item.dc:title: Dynamic stereomutation of vinylcyclopropanes with metalloradicals
item.dc:creator: Marvin Mendel
Teresa M. Karl
Jegor Hamm
Sherif J. Kaldas
Theresa Sperger
Bhaskar Mondal
Franziska Schoenebeck

item.title: ‘It can feel like there’s no way out’ — political scientists face pushback on their work
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02026-z

In a year in which numerous countries are going to the polls, many election-watching scientists are under pressure.
item.dc:title: ‘It can feel like there’s no way out’ — political scientists face pushback on their work
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis
Alison Abbott

item.title: Spinal cord ‘atlas’ offers unprecedented insights into injuries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02069-2

A model in mice that charts precisely how different cells respond to damage could aid the development of new treatments for spinal injuries.
item.dc:title: Spinal cord ‘atlas’ offers unprecedented insights into injuries
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Put people at the heart of schizophrenia research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02024-1

Scientists, health-care professionals, carers and individuals affected by the condition must work more closely with one another to improve people’s lives.
item.dc:title: Put people at the heart of schizophrenia research
item.dc:creator: Constanza Morén

item.title: Not all ‘open source’ AI models are actually open: here’s a ranking
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02012-5

Many of the large language models that power chatbots claim to be open, but restrict access to code and training data.
item.dc:title: Not all ‘open source’ AI models are actually open: here’s a ranking
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: First encounter with SARS-CoV-2: immune portraits of COVID susceptibility
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01644-x

Controlled infection with SARS-CoV-2 of people who hadn’t previously been exposed to the virus reveals how molecular and cellular signatures of the immune response portend effective defence against COVID-19.
item.dc:title: First encounter with SARS-CoV-2: immune portraits of COVID susceptibility
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Israelow
Akiko Iwasaki

item.title: Lights in the storm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02031-2

An unplanned visit.
item.dc:title: Lights in the storm
item.dc:creator: Jan Marry

item.title: How farming could become the ultimate climate-change tool
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02036-x

A generation of farmers and scientists are finding ways to sequester carbon in the soil while improving crop yields.
item.dc:title: How farming could become the ultimate climate-change tool
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Human neuroscience is entering a new era — it mustn’t forget its human dimension
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02022-3

The field is taking a leap forward thanks to innovative technologies, such as artificial intelligence. Researchers must improve consent procedures and public involvement.
item.dc:title: Human neuroscience is entering a new era — it mustn’t forget its human dimension

item.title: Graphene combines computer logic and memory in a single device
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01642-z

A sheet of graphene sandwiched between electrolytes can host independently tunable proton and electron currents — setting the stage for a device that serves both computer-memory and logic functions.
item.dc:title: Graphene combines computer logic and memory in a single device
item.dc:creator: Manu Jaiswal

item.title: Sensory secrets of penis and clitoris unlocked after more than 150 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02058-5

Low-frequency vibrations arouse genital nerve cells in mice — a finding that might lead to treatments for erectile dysfunction and more.
item.dc:title: Sensory secrets of penis and clitoris unlocked after more than 150 years
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Daily briefing: Cheaper versions of drugs like Wegovy are on their way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02077-2

The patents on blockbuster weight-loss drugs are running out and companies are poised to make lower-cost versions. Plus, astronomers see a black hole wake up for the first time and how long is too long for a freight train.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Cheaper versions of drugs like Wegovy are on their way
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Sex organs sense vibrations through specialized touch neurons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01645-w

A little-studied sensory structure called the Krause corpuscle is responsible for detecting light touch and is essential for normal sexual behaviour in mice. The findings have interesting implications for human sexual intimacy.
item.dc:title: Sex organs sense vibrations through specialized touch neurons
item.dc:creator: Anastasia-Maria Zavitsanou
Ishmail Abdus-Saboor

item.title: How to address agriculture’s water woes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02037-w

Water isn’t the only challenge facing agriculture in a climate-altered future, but a lack of it could have catastrophic effects.
item.dc:title: How to address agriculture’s water woes
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Cheaper versions of blockbuster obesity drugs are being created in India and China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02044-x

As the patents on various weight-loss drugs near expiry, companies in India and China are vying to make lower-cost versions that will widen access to such treatments.
item.dc:title: Cheaper versions of blockbuster obesity drugs are being created in India and China
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: How do fish know where a sound comes from? Scientists have an answer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02068-3

A dual hearing system helps fish pinpoint a sound’s source — plus uncovering the secrets of the sensory structures that respond to touch during sex.
item.dc:title: How do fish know where a sound comes from? Scientists have an answer
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Pressure and particle motion enable fish to sense the direction of sound
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01509-3

Scientists have long sought to explain how fish can sense the direction of sound, given the challenges that hearing underwater poses. An experimental study testing a variety of models now provides some answers.
item.dc:title: Pressure and particle motion enable fish to sense the direction of sound
item.dc:creator: Catherine E. Carr

item.title: Could rats and dogs detect disease better than the finest lab equipment?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01751-9

The animals’ keen sense of smell could improve the detection of illnesses such as cancer and tuberculosis.
item.dc:title: Could rats and dogs detect disease better than the finest lab equipment?
item.dc:creator: Sarah DeWeerdt

item.title: ‘Fighting fire with fire’ — using LLMs to combat LLM hallucinations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01641-0

The number of errors produced by an LLM can be reduced by grouping its outputs into semantically similar clusters. Remarkably, this task can be performed by a second LLM, and the method’s efficacy can be evaluated by a third.
item.dc:title: ‘Fighting fire with fire’ — using LLMs to combat LLM hallucinations
item.dc:creator: Karin Verspoor
